Award.AwardTitle: The New Mexico STEM Transfer Coalition: Improving the Success and Matriculation Rates of Two-Year College STEM Students from Small, Minority-Serving Colleges in Northern New Mexico

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a consortium of six minority-serving colleges in New Mexico formed to increase the number of associates and baccalaureate degrees granted in STEM fields. The consortium is led by New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology (New Mexico Tech), a state science and engineering institution, and includes four community colleges in rural northern New Mexico, and Northern New Mexico College - an institution that is currently in transition from being a community college to a four year degree granting institution. The consortium has a cultural affinity because the participating colleges are small, enrolling less than 3,000 students each, and located in rural areas with high percentages of Hispanic, Native American, low-income, and first-generation college students. The program of work is based upon institutional self-study that has identified the major systemic and institutional obstacles to students completing STEM degrees. Project activities include:
1. Creating and implementing fully developed 2+2 or 2+3 degree plans and reverse transfer opportunities.
2. Enhancing advisement, student development, and undergraduate research opportunities to improve 2-year and 4-year graduation rates and to facilitate the transfer of 2-year students into baccalaureate programs.
3. Establishing paid research opportunities to provide STEM students with income while attending school, foster their interest in STEM careers, and develop student-employer relationships prior to graduation.
4. Developing and improving pre-engineering and science programs to establish consistent, high-standard programs at the 2-year colleges in the consortium.
5. Building Northern New Mexico College's capacity to offer high quality four-year STEM degrees.

Over the five-year grant period, the project is projected to double the number of STEM Associate of Science degrees awarded at the 2-year colleges, triple the number of transfers to New Mexico Tech and Northern New Mexico College, and increase their graduation rates at both schools. Overall the project plans to serve 610 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this grant were to increase the numbers of students transferring from five schools in northern New Mexico ((Santa Fe Community College, Luna Community College, UNM Taos, UNM Los Alamos and Northern NM College) and to prepare them for moving on to a four year degree. We determined that many potential transfer students at these schools had either not heard of NM Tech or if they had, they heard it is a rigorous school and difficult to graduate from. Another issue we identified was that many students transferred to NM Tech having taken in excess of 60 credits at their school, but only a few transferred as required classes for any degree at NM Tech. This was obviously a concern for the students and it also meant that they could run out of financial aid before completing a four year degree at NM Tech. Furthermore, a significant number of transfer students had not taken many math classes, and so the time they spent improving their math skills extended the time it took them to graduate.

The grant allowed us to develop a number of approaches to address these issues. We hired a Transfer and Articulation specialist to work with the counselors at the partner schools in identifying which classes would transfer to NM Tech, and to work on articulation agreements with each partner school. We provided information on the transfer process to four year schools, scholarship opportunities and on the potential career choices once they graduated with a four year degree.

To overcome the negative perception of NM Tech, we found having potential transfer students meet with current NM Tech students who had already transferred from the same school was the largest single factor encouraging students to transfer to NM Tech. We brought groups of students from each partner school to NM Tech so that they could meet other students and meet with faculty in their area of interest.

The grant also contained funds for summer internships at Los Alamos National Labs, the largest employer in northern NM. This enabled students to experience the types of career opportunities available on completing their four year degree. It also provided motivation to continue along a career path in the Science and Technology area.

As a result of the project we increased the numbers of students transferring to NM Tech from the partner schools. We found that the transfer students completed their four year degrees at the same rate as freshman students, which means that our counseling prepared them well for their experience at NM Tech.
